content.user_title: Apply DRY Principle to Refactor Code
content.value_statement: Duplicate code creates maintenance nightmares where fixes must be applied everywhere. This skill provides a systematic 4-step workflow to identify, abstract, replace, and verify code duplication elimination for cleaner, more maintainable codebases.
actual_capabilities: Identifies code duplication patterns including copy-paste, magic numbers, and structural repetition
Guides abstraction of repeated logic into reusable functions, classes, or constants
Provides systematic replacement strategy for eliminating duplication across codebase
Includes verification and testing workflow to ensure refactoring safety
Offers checklists for identifying and avoiding refactoring pitfalls
limitations: Does not automatically detect or fix duplicate code - requires human review
Does not execute code or run tests - provides guidance only
Does not modify files directly - user must apply changes manually
Does not integrate with IDE refactoring tools

use_cases.title: Eliminate Code Duplication
use_cases.description: Systematically find and remove copy-paste code to improve maintainability and reduce bugs

use_cases.title: Validate DRY Compliance
use_cases.description: Check code submissions for duplication patterns and recommend appropriate refactoring

use_cases.title: Establish Refactoring Standards
use_cases.description: Guide teams on systematic approaches to reducing technical debt through DRY refactoring

prompt_templates.title: Basic DRY Refactor
prompt_templates.prompt: I have code with repeated logic. Apply the DRY principle to identify the duplication and create a reusable abstraction.

prompt_templates.title: Magic Numbers
prompt_templates.prompt: Find and replace all magic numbers and hardcoded strings in this code with properly named constants.

prompt_templates.title: Structural Refactor
prompt_templates.prompt: These functions implement similar logic with different variable names. Create a generic abstraction that handles both cases.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply the complete DRY workflow: identify all duplication, abstract into reusable components, replace all occurrences, and verify the changes maintain original behavior.

best_practices: Wait until code appears at least twice before abstracting - premature abstraction creates unnecessary complexity
Run tests before and after refactoring to ensure behavior remains identical
Use descriptive names that explain what the abstraction does, not how it does it
anti_patterns: Copy-pasting code instead of creating reusable abstractions
Over-abstracting with overly generic functions that are hard to understand
Replacing only some instances of duplicate code while leaving others

faq.question: Does this skill automatically detect duplicate code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance on identifying duplication patterns. You must review the code and apply the recommended patterns yourself.

faq.question: What programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: The skill is language-agnostic. Examples use JavaScript, Python, and TypeScript, but the principles apply to any programming language.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my code files directly?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides instructions and code examples. You must manually apply the refactoring changes to your codebase.

faq.question: Is my code data sent anywhere during refactoring?
faq.answer: No. This is a pure prompt-based skill with no network access. Your code remains completely private and local.

faq.question: How do I verify refactoring did not break anything?
faq.answer: The skill provides testing guidance. Run your existing test suite before and after refactoring. The skill includes unit test examples for abstracted functions.

faq.question: How is this different from IDE refactoring tools?
faq.answer: IDE tools automate mechanical refactoring like renaming. This skill provides strategic guidance on what to refactor and how to design clean abstractions.
